sections.content: Who am I to write this guide?
I am Saiqo :)

I started my SEO content writing journey in the middle of 2021 (yes, wayyy before GPT), and in the past 4 years, I have (ghost)written over 340 blogs and articles for over 55 clients in 15+ industries. In the mid of 2022, I got a Level Two Seller badge on Fiverr and then in early  2023, my Fiverr got banned. And I shifted to LinkedIn. I started on Upwork in January 2024…, and in March 2024, I got the top-rated badge.
I have earned $20k+ in the past two years solely from SEO blog posts. Those blog posts helped me feed my family of 7, travel almost 65% of Pakistan, and my new home is just being constructed.
Now I have a non-typical DFY blog writing agency, and we manage our client's blog from scratch.
Sounds like I’m writing a resume:)
But anyways….I know a thing or two about SEO blog writing, and you will learn everything I know.
Fair enough?
Ok, but what’s this SAIQO thing?
Saiqo is an acronym. It stands for;
S = Search Intent.
A = Auntnticity.
I = Insightful.
Q = Quality.
O = Original
These are ‘elements’ that make a blog post ‘rank-worthy’ and ‘read-worthy.’
Why am I writing this guide when you can literally find 1000s of SEO content writing guides on Google and tutorials on YouTube?
There were times when I was a total nut…and used to get excessively nervous when clients approached me for a project.
What to chat with the client…how to start the project…what if I can't complete the project…what if the client gets angry with me…what if they curse me….were some of my first thoughts…

At that time, I did not find any guide to show me the process…the roadmap needed to complete a client’s blog post project. Some guides get too deep into research and ignore other factors. Some touch on all the aspects (On-page SEO, structure, etc.) but miss other details, like how to research and outline stuff. I really wish I knew everything that I know today. But today, when I know… I want to transfer everything, in the hope that it will save you time…loads of time and stress.
What you should expect from this guide?
There are two things in SEO blog writing…
After reading this guide, you won’t become an “EXPERT” SEO blog writer.
Writing needs practice. Expertise comes with grinding and writing daily. You also need discipline, a constant reading habit, a curious mind, and an itch to serve the reader with THE best.
No one can spoon-feed you “good writing.” And there is no ‘good writing’ as ‘good’ is always subjective. That is your part to excel.

This guide will show you a roadmap, a method…, and a way to write blogs the right way. You won’t need to take any other courses…or spend countless days and nights just navigating the process…as I once struggled to do.

This guide is about the process from scratch to end with important concepts you must know. In other words, I can safely say that this guide has all the ingredients you need to cook a perfect blog….but as you know, every cook cooks differently (and as per their cheffing talent) even given the same ingredients…so is the case with this guide….
The better you can write…the better this guide will serve.

sections.content: Some Basics Before You Get into Writing
First thing First…
Who Needs SEO Blog Posts and What’s Their Purpose?
If you already know this, you can simply skip it and let me talk to the ones who are just getting started.
Who needs blog posts?
Widely speaking, anyone who has a website on Google need blog posts. We call them “website owners.”
And those website owners fall into 5 major categories (I have categorized them in ‘most demanded’ to ‘least demanded’ order);
Product Providers

Think about ANY type and kind of business that sells tangible (physical) products. They might operate through e-commerce platforms like Amazon, Shopify, or eBay or have their website on a CMS (Content Management System) like WordPress, Content Hub, or Magento. In some cases, they might even have both—an e-commerce store and a separate website on a CMS.
So, anyway…you get the idea; any business owner selling physical products needs a blog post writer.
Software as Service Providers (or SaaS Founders)

They have products but not physical ones. Think about tools (like AI writing tools, video editing, image editing, or any AI tool), extensions (like chrome or web extensions), and software (like Microsoft, Jira, etc.).
There have been boatloads of AI tools in the market since the AI boom. And now there is a tool for almost any task….so yes, SaaS founders need SEO blog writers.
Digital Service Providers

Think about ANY person who has a digital service to offer falls under this category. Freelancers, digital marketing agency owners, marketers, coaches, consultants, therapists, psychologists, trainers, and teachers…. all have digital services to offer, and they all need a blog post writer to write content.
Niche Content Creators

These are the folks who don’t have any service or product business. They create a website on a specific niche like lifestyle, travel, or food and create content around it. Their business is to get revenue via Google AdSense or affiliate marketing. They need a blog post writer to write content around their niche.
Nonprofits and Educational Institutes

Nonprofit organizations (NGOs, churches, charities, etc.) need SEO blog writers. Similarly, educational institutes (Govt & public schools & colleges, vocational training institutes, academies, etc.) also need SEO blog writers.
My purpose is to give you a broad perspective on whom you can write SEO blog posts for.
If you have not written any blog post before, just sit with yourself and think from these 5 categories…who would you like to write for?
It will help you a lot, I promise.
NOTE: I didn’t explicitly use the category “business owners.” Because, somehow, everyone owning a website has some kind of business to do or offer. We all are business owners.
Now….
What’s the purpose of a blog post?
Mainly two;
Get organic traffic (number of visitors or users).

Nothing on the planet earth is better than blog posts to get ORGANIC, long-term, sustainable traffic on your website. I can bet my last penny for this…and win. Everyone knows it. Blog posts bring visitors, and those visitors convert into customers or clients.
Build Authority

Ok, this is somehow ambiguous. What kind of authority? A business owner with a physical product, service, or software must write about it. That’s the only way to “educate” their target audience/customers. And that’s the only way to “differentiate” your offer/service/product from your competitors. And that’s the only way to describe their problems and offer solutions. And that’s the only way to inform them about the problems they might face soon.
So when a website owner educates/informs their readers and differentiates themselves from their competitors…it builds authority…and authority builds trust.
Now you might be having a question…
“Do people still read blog posts?”
Yes, they do. And I suggest you Google this question. You will get stats and logic and all the reasons why in 2024, 83% of internet users read blog posts.
That’s your first homework.
Come up with at least 5 reasons & logics why people read blog posts.
What can you, as an SEO writer, promise your client?
Sure….blog posts do a lot for a website owner. But you, as an SEO blog writer, can’t guarantee rankings (trrafic), sales or revenue.
Why?
Because written content is just one piece of the puzzle.
Here are all of the things that are involved in getting rankings;

So, you see……SEO content writer comes in the middle of this process. If keyword research is not done correctly, or if the content strategy is not strong enough…the blog you write for your client will not get rankings easily. After you write a blog, your client uploads it on their website…if they don’t upload it properly, it will affect rankings. After uploading the blog post, your client needs to take care of off-page and technical SEO.

So, no one can guarantee rankings if any of this is weak. AND there is no guarantee for rankings whatsoever. There are some 200+ KNOWN factors that Google takes into account…and there are MANY unknown factors, too.
So what does this all mean? What should you promise to your clients? Because the whole purpose of a blog is to increase organic traffic….
Here is what I promise to my clients…
That is pretty much all I can promise. I promise my client that the content I write will be 2x better as the existing one. It will be unique and fulfill the purpose and their requirements.
Now let’s see what kind of clients you usually have to deal with.
Know Your Client
Let me set the scenario for you…
You're an SEO blog writer working for a client. The negotiation phase is over, and you've successfully closed the deal. By now, you have a sense of where your client falls on the spectrum.
Most clients will fall somewhere in between these two extremes.

These clients provide you with everything: keywords, a complete topic with outlines, target audience details, the blog's purpose, word count, graphics, and every other detail. If you're just starting, these clients are a blessing. They guide you through the process, telling you exactly what to include and avoid.
Typically, these clients come from content writing agencies, marketing agencies, or senior freelancers looking to outsource some of their work.

Note: Some clients in this category can be a bit of a challenge. They often think they know everything about the job market trends, writing, and its process. This can lead to them devaluing your rates and trying to micromanage you. My best advice is to avoid them initially, but as you gain experience, you'll learn how to handle them effectively.

These clients only know one thing: "Our website needs 'written content' to drive more traffic, so we need to hire an SEO writer." That's it. They often have a new website, no content strategy, and little understanding of the process. They're typically impatient for results, and about 80% will stop publishing SEO content just after two or three months.

You'll mostly find these clients on LinkedIn or other social media platforms. You can work with them if you know how to educate and convince them and if you have some knowledge of SEO and content strategy (which most mid-level SEO writers do).

Then there’s a middle category—clients who don't pretend to know everything but aren't new to the industry. They understand what an SEO writer can do and what they need to provide. They communicate clearly and have fair expectations.
Working with the all-knowing is easy while dealing with the new ones can be a bit harder.

It's important to understand and assess the type of client you're dealing with. That’s why you often hear and read sentences like “Know your ideal customers” and “Understand your ICP (ideal client personas).” When you know your client, you write better and overdeliver.
So, take the time to get to know your client and understand where you stand. That's your first step.
In any case…
All clear until now?
But we need to clarify 1 more basic concept to help you in your overall SEO blog writing journey.
Know What You Are Writing
You know YOU, your client, and what you have signed up for….here is one more thing you need to know before even thinking of writing anything for your client.
It’s…what format and type of blog you will write.
Formats of Blog Posts

The format is the “structure” or “style” in which the content is presented. Different formats serve different purposes and appeal to different audiences. (Don’t confuse it with the ‘inner’ formatting of an individual blog post. I have discussed it in unit 4 as well).
There are more than 15 formats of blog posts. But we will focus on major 7.
(For the love of writing…don’t skip this part:)
Listicles
This format typically features a numbered list. This type is popular nowadays because it is easy to read and skimmable.
Listicles often include tips, strategies, or recommendations.
Examples;
How-to Posts/Guides (also sometimes referred to as long-form posts)
This format provides step-by-step instructions on how to accomplish a specific task or achieve a particular goal. How-to guides are usually detailed, ‘practical,’ and informative.
Examples;
‘What’ and ‘Why’ Posts.
Also known as “explanatory” posts. Their intent is purely “educational”. The “what” format explains a “concept.” The “why” format explains why a “concept” is important.
Example;
What is Blog writing? (‘What’ format).
Why is Blog Writing Important? (‘Why’ format).
Curated Posts
As the name suggests, you ‘curate’ content by researching a specific topic extensively. You will gather statistics and relevant information from credible sources and write in an easy-to-consume way.
Examples;

Thought-leader or Opinionated Posts

This format is used when writers (in our case, your client…and they hire an expert…YOU) share their ‘expert’ viewpoint or opinion on a specific topic. Thought-leadership post style usually points out things like where the industry is heading…or what will be the results of recent updates in a particular industry.
Examples;
Case Studies
Case studies are in-depth analyses of real-life situations, projects, or experiences. They often include background information, challenges faced, solutions implemented, and results achieved.
Mostly, this format is used to show expertise.

Comparisons
You simply compare two (or more) things (products, platforms, services) here.
And oftentimes, you share your take/viewpoint/experience for each thing…

I shared these formats because they help in determining the tone and style of a blog post. But, no need to stress about memorizing every type and format.

Some are obvious and can be identified just by looking at your client's title or topic. Other times, when you're given a primary or short-tail keyword, you'll conduct a SERP analysis (discussed in detail below) to decide on the format
Ok, just 1 more thing…
Types of Blogs SEO Writers Usually Deal With…
In 90% of the cases, you will write for two types of blogs...
1. Money-Making Blogs

These blogs exist primarily to generate income, often through various monetization strategies such as Google AdSense, affiliate marketing, or brand partnerships. Your client doesn’t offer a product or service directly but focuses on driving traffic to their blog to earn revenue.
Types of Money-Making Blogs:

Affiliate Blogs: These blogs earn through affiliate commissions by promoting products or services other companies offer. They often publish product reviews, top product lists, or how-to guides that link to affiliate products.

For example, blogs about electronics, beauty products, health supplements, or home appliances often rely on affiliate income. Each time a reader clicks through and makes a purchase, the blog owner earns a commission.

Ad-Supported Blogs: These websites rely heavily on ad revenue, often through platforms like Google AdSense. Ad-supported blogs usually cover topics with mass appeal to attract high traffic volumes, such as entertainment, news, and lifestyle, or general interest topics like food, fashion, and DIY. The goal is to generate as many page views as possible to maximize ad impressions.

Niche Content Blogs: Some blogs focus on a very specific niche—like personal finance, travel, or pet care—and earn through partnerships or sponsored content. These blogs often establish authority in a specific field and collaborate with brands to promote products or services, earning income from the brand partnerships.
As an SEO writer for these blogs, your primary focus will be writing content that attracts high traffic, engages readers, and ranks well on search engines to drive monetization.
2. Business Blogs

Business blogs are tied directly to a company’s products or services. Their main goal is not direct income from the blog itself but rather to drive awareness, attract potential customers, and educate readers in a way that supports the business's offerings. This type of blog is critical for content marketing strategies, and your writing should help showcase the company’s expertise, answer customer questions, or demonstrate product benefits.
Types of Business Blogs:

Service-Based Blogs: Businesses offering services—such as marketing agencies, financial consulting firms, legal services, or IT support—use blogs to attract clients by educating them on relevant topics.
For instance, a digital marketing agency might publish blog posts about SEO strategies, social media marketing tips, or case studies that illustrate how their services have helped clients succeed.

E-Commerce Blogs: E-commerce businesses often use blogs to promote their products and build brand awareness. These blogs typically include product-related content such as buying guides, product comparisons, seasonal gift ideas, and how-to articles.
For example, an online store selling fitness equipment might publish blogs about workout routines, fitness trends, or guides on selecting the right equipment.
SaaS (Software as a Service) Blogs:

Companies offering digital products or software tools—like project management software, CRM platforms, or cloud storage solutions—use their blogs to educate potential customers about their tools and how they solve common problems. SaaS blogs often feature tutorials, industry news, or expert tips on maximizing the value of their software.

B2B (Business-to-Business) Blogs: These blogs target other businesses, and the content focuses on more technical or industry-specific topics. B2B companies use blogs to educate potential customers on complex services or products, such as manufacturing equipment, logistics software, or corporate training programs.
Why am I telling you all this?

It is essential to understand which type of writing you will write–It will help you determine the overall tone/style of the writing and the purpose of your client. Business blogs often have a formal, professional, and ‘expert’ tone. Personal blogs usually have an informal and conversational tone.  Money-making blogs could have a mixture of both, depending on the topic.

When you know the ‘type’, you do better research. For instance, you look for stats, reports, research, and official case studies for business blogs. For personal blogs, you search for people’s opinions, viewpoints, and experiences on social media like YT, FB, Insta, or sites like Quora or Reddit, or maybe online reviews on review sites.

Important Concepts
Everything you need to ace your SEO content writing game
1): On-Page SEO Elements (what you should consider as an SEO writer)
SEO has three main categories:

As an SEO writer, you are primarily concerned with on-page SEO elements. On-page SEO refers to all the functions and operations you can perform on a web page, which contains content ( text, visuals, videos, etc. ).
List of on-page SEO elements that you, as a writer, can take care of:
Meta Tags
Meta tags for a blog include the SEO title and meta description.
It should include the primary/seed keyword and be catchy, concise, and clear. The ideal length is between 50 to 70 characters (8 to 12 words).
You can add secondary keywords in the title, but only if it sounds natural. Ensure the title reads like a complete sentence, not just a phrase or separate words.

According to Google Search Central Blog (and SEMrush), Google does not use keywords in meta descriptions for web ranking. The purpose of the meta-description is to tell the reader whether the content of the page is relevant to their search query. If the meta description tells the reader they get what they are searching for, they will click and read the post.
What can you do to optimize the meta description?

Simple, clear, and no-fluff MDs are always the best. I write the meta description of the blog post at the end. This way, I am more familiar with the topic and know the most STRONG points to convince readers to read the blog.
ALT (Alternative) Text for Images.

If your client provides you with the image or asks you to use ‘visuals’ in the blog post, they must be SEO-optimized. ALT text makes this possible. Alternative text means the “description of the image.” In other words, you have to describe the image in words.

Most users/readers will never actually see the ALT text (it’s hidden in the code of an image tag), but if, due to some reason (slow site loading speed or slow internet of the user), the image does not load, the user/reader will be able to see the description of the image.

ALT text is also important for Web Accessibility. There are people with disabilities (blindness) who use the Internet with screen-reading technology… so a descriptive image (image with ALT text) helps them ‘visualize’ what’s in the image.
Now think about this….how will you describe a visual to a blind person? That’s exactly how you should write your ALT text.

If you are new and have never written any ALT text for an image, practice it. Take any image from Google and try to describe it concisely and clearly within 20-30 words.
Keyword Placement in Headings and Text
Are you familiar with Keyword Stuffing?
Yes, that is a decade-old concept. Some people think it still works. That’s why I get questions and complaints like;
You need to integrate keywords naturally and organically so readers don’t get annoyed.
This is one of the major requirements of ‘people-first’ content. And when you ‘stuff’ keywords, your reader gets to know it right there.
Now, that does not mean you forget about keywords and write whatever comes to you.

As an SEO writer, it's your job to write strategically. In addition to primary keywords, you have secondary keywords and LSIs (remember them? If not, go back and revise). So, your content must have primary and secondary keywords and LSI terms. That’s where you need to be strategic.
Typically, the Keyword Density is 1-2%, meaning you should use a keyword once after every 100 words (but again, only if that makes sense).

Similarly, keywords in headings are important only if they naturally fit in. It also depends on the topic you’re writing on. For instance, if it’s a how-to guide…your headings will revolve around the primary keyword so you can easily cover the keywords in H2s. But if it’s a listicle, you cannot cover the primary keyword as it is (most of the time).
Here is what you can do to optimize your headings for SEO;

The heading/subheading should be the crux of the body so that if a reader is in a rush and doesn’t want to read the whole thing you wrote under the heading, they get an idea from the heading itself. It’s a best practice to optimize your content for skimmers. It also increases readability.

You don’t always need to include keywords in the headings. You can use variations and synonyms (also known as LSIs).  Google gets the idea through the context of the content of what you’re talking about.
Heading hierarchy is the order of the headings and subheadings.
There should be ONLY one H1 in your blog post (we often call it the title page or SEO title).
After H1, all major headings are H2s. Any subpoint/subheading in an H2 will be H3 (and any subpoint in H3 will be H4, and so on).
H1. (The title of the blog post)
>H2 (The first major heading after H1)
>H3 (The subheading of the H2 or the subpoint that you want to cover in H2)
>H4 (The subheading you want to cover in H3)
>H2 (Another major heading)
And the structure follows like this.
Most of the time, we don’t need to go to H4. And the best practice is to stop on H3 anyway. Make a bullet list if you have further info/subpoints in H3 to discuss.
Internal and External linking
Internal or interlinking links a specific blog post to others on the SAME website.
External or outbound links link your blog post to similar or relevant blog posts on a DIFFERENT domain/website.
There is no rocket science here. It’s simple.
Why do we do it?
Two reasons;
So, you see? You don’t just take any word or phrase and put a hyperlink to it….you only do it when it makes sense and is helpful both for the reader and Google.
If you are writing on a given keyword or topic and your client asks you to put interlinks and external links, the first thing you do after writing the blog post is find the anchor text.
Anchor (as the word itself indicates, that ‘something used to hold another thing firmly/securely) text is the phrase or word you hyperlink to another blog post.

Let's say your client’s niche is health and nutrition, and you’re assigned to write a blog post with the keyword “low-calorie healthy diet.” Healthy diet is the main keyword here, and you’ve got to include internal and external links.
Here are some types of anchor texts you can look out for;

This anchor text type uses the keyword or phrase you’re targeting for SEO. For example, if your keyword is "healthy diet," you would use "healthy diet" as the anchor text and find another blog post on the website written on/about healthy diet.
This includes a variation of the keyword you’re targeting. For example, "benefits of a healthy diet" if your main keyword is "healthy diet."
This uses your brand name as the anchor text, such as "greenlife,"  and you can hyperlink to the company's About or Home page.
This uses non-descriptive text like "click here" or "read more."
ALWAYS void this type of anchor text.
This type of anchor text uses synonyms or related terms to provide context. For example, if your keyword is "healthy diet," you might use "nutritious eating habits" as semantic anchor text.

This involves embedding the link within a sentence or phrase that naturally fits the context of your content. It helps provide a smooth reading experience and is highly effective for SEO. For example, "To maintain a balanced diet, you should eat more nutrient-rich foods. (hyperlink the sentence to a blog post about a balanced diet and nutrient-rich foods).
The anchor text selection criteria are the same for both internal and external links.

2): Satisfy EEAT as a Generalist Writer
This is one of the most debated topics after Google’s Helpful Content Update (HCU).
I’ll be short and quick here and try my best to make it easy for you.
First of all, what the hell is EEAT?
It’s an acronym for;
E = Experience
E = Expertise
A = Authoritativeness
T = Trustworthiness
Let’s briefly translate what this ‘vague’ acronym is trying to say;
‘The content creator (writer) has (first-hand) experience and expertise in the topic. The content has authority and is trustable.
Well, this is what it apparently sounds like.
Is EEAT an SEO factor?
No. Not a direct one.

It’s part of how Google evaluates the quality of your content. Google published its quality rating guideline for the first time in 2013. In 2014, they introduced E-E-T. In December 2022, they added another E for ‘experience’.
So, EEAT is a component of Google’s Search Quality Rater Guidelines (SQRG is Google’s 170-page lengthy guide; you can find it on the Google Search Central Blog).
Google mentioned two kinds of ratings;
Everything (technical and non-technical)  on the web page, including content and visuals.
The users’ search needs.
Did they get the information they were looking for?
Did they find the specific product/service they were looking for?
Etc.
Google uses the EEAT formula to check the content against these ratings. Google gets this rating from the OVERALL website content, domain authority, links, etc.

Another important point that you should know here is that EEAT is more applicable to YMYL (Your Money, Your Life) niches. YMYL niches cover topics that directly impact someone’s life, such as financial conditions, well-being, etc. (You can also Google this phrase). In these topics, a writer’s opinion, expertise, and experience could really impact the user’s life.
So, the content in these niches must be specifically reliable or EEAT-aligned.
So, even if EEAT is not a direct ranking factor, it does contribute to rankings. EEAT-aligned content will definitely get better rankings than non-EEAT-aligned content.
Although Google evaluates the overall content of a website against EEAT, a single blog post also has EEAT elements.
And that’s where you as an SEO content writer, play your role to help your client get EEAT-aligned content.
Let’s see how.
How do you (as an SEO writer for your clients) satisfy EEAT, especially when you are a generalist writer and don’t have firsthand experience/expertise in the niche?
See, we are not concerned with how much content the website already has, the domain authority, or links.

Let’s assume you are writing on a provided topic/keyword and don’t know how and when your client will publish the content. They are not going to give you bylines (when the client gives you credit and mentions you as their SEO writer on their site). So, how will you satisfy EEAT as a writer?
Let’s dive in one by one.
E = Experience
Let me rephrase this for you;
It’s basically ‘the first-hand experience of a writer.’
A blog post that includes real-life data, examples, instances, and use cases is more effective than one that only has no data and generic, surface-level content.
The depth of the content shows the writer's ‘experience’. The logicality and practicality of the real-life use cases and examples also show how much real-life experience the writer has.
But here is the thing…
You can’t possibly have the ‘first-hand’ experience of every topic you write as an SEO writer. That’s where your research skills come in.
Yes, RESEARCH is a SKILL.
So…If your research is good, you can;

But keep in mind that you can’t fake experience. They say ‘experience speaks. ' So always try to get the real experience. Spend some time (even if you already know it) with the topic and learn about it.
E = Expertise
Let me rephrase it for you;
“The expertise of a writer as a subject matter expert”.

I call it the ability to simplify complex topics so your target audience can clearly understand. An expert is one who knows how to convey the message (or information) in a digestible, easy-to-understand way.
Also, the expert knows how to convince and persuade readers (especially if you are writing something with a commercial intent).
You don’t have to tell your readers you’re an expert…you need to show them through your words.
It’s like ‘walk the talk.
All you have to do is;
- Use the most persuasive content angle (the best way possible to convey your message/information).
- Write in the language of your target audience
When you spend enough time on any topic, you can develop expert-level knowledge. Again…it depends on your research skills.
A = Authoritativeness
(NOTE: Authority highly refers to the site…and your client…
But as a writer I believe that we can still contribute to it.
Who are you as a writer? Does your profile complement what you’re talking about?
For instance, at the start of this guide, I wrote my short intro…and it made you read until now. That's my authority as a writer.
But you can’t write your intro in every blog post…and what if your client does not credit you with the bylines (mention you as the writer on their blog page and interlink your social profiles)?
You can still show your authority in a single blog post.
How?
You probably have forgotten who I am…but while you are reading the content, something in it is telling you that I have the ‘authority’ to write what I’m writing.
Confidence.
You need to be confident in your tone, style, and the way you structure sentences and paragraphs.
All this gives the reader an authoritative impression of the writer. And they call it ‘concieved authority.’

If the writer has an online presence (and is known by something), this is called perceived credibility. For instance, Neil Patel is a known digital marketer. When you read a blog post about digital marketing written by him, you believe in what he writes.
BUT…
As I said, authority (in Google’s terms)...is the overall authority of the website.
How many people are referring to that website or a single page? Also known as the backlinks.
Google gets the authority signals by looking at whether other (websites) are recognizing your website as an authority.
But again…
People will only refer to your website if it has high-quality, valuable, and helpful content.
(People buy backlinks to show authority…but one only gets highly relevant and beneficial backlinks if the content is well written).
At the end of the day, the ball’s in your court as a writer.
T = Trustworthiness
I can rephrase it to;
“The honesty and truthfulness of a writer.”
Your content is trustworthy enough if you’re:
Trustworthiness also depends on the site somehow. For example, the website is secure, and consumers/readers' protection is strong and up-to-date. The website has a smooth and clean UX and UI, etc.
3): Content Readability
Generally readability means that your content is readable for ANYONE who is reading the content. For this, we usually consider the following two pointers;
Sentence structure and length
The sentence should be clear and meaningful. Here is what I do to make sure clarity and meaningfulness in a sentence;
Daily-life easy-to-understand vocabulary
Fancy and academic vocabulary make the content hard to read. So, use words and phrases that you use in your daily life conversations. For instance, instead of ‘integral,’ use ‘important.’
The objective is to make your writing EASY in your reader’s eyes. So, if they’re in a hurry or skimming/scanning your content, their mind can quickly process words and their meanings.
That’s why you’re often told that write for a 7th grader.
I use the Hemingway editor to evaluate the hard-to-read words/phrases and lengthy sentences.
Grammarly also tells you readability and content performance scores. You can use that, too. It also gives you suggestions to rewrite the sentences.

All of this is a general conception regarding readability. Which is not wrong or irrelevant and you must make your content easy to understand and read. The only logic behind this readability concept is that readers usually have very disturbed concentration (they’d be juggling with so much stuff in their head), so they must think about WHAT you’re writing – not about HOW you’re writing it.
But readability is NOT just easier vocabulary and simple sentence structure.
Readability means your content is “understandable” for your “TARGET” reader.

Depending on the topic and niche, your reader’s “reading level” varies. That means something understandable for one type of reader may not be readable for another type. For instance, if I am writing a technical blog post in a cybersecurity niche, and using industry jargon and niche terms, then chances are that my content would not make much sense to someone who does not know anything about cybersecurity.
On the other hand, if you use daily life lingo and vocabulary while writing for someone who is pretty knowledgeable about the niche, you will sound fluff and irrelevant.
You get the idea.
That said, the 7th-grader formula can’t be implemented here. Your objective is to make your content easy to read for your target audience, whether their level is 7th or 12th—it doesn’t matter.
Considering this, the readability of a blog post totally depends on the topic and the target reader. Now;
So, how do you ensure that the content you’re writing is readable for your target audience?
Before you start writing, ask yourself;
The readability rule of thumb while writing a blog post is that your content must be “compatible” with your reader’s reading level.
No rocket science at all. It's as simple as how you write differently when texting a friend than writing an email to your boss or client.
4): Writing Tone
Writing tone refers to how your content "sounds" to your reader. It shapes how the message is perceived and can influence/trigger the reader’s engagement and response.
There are four common tones to choose from:
Professional & Formal

This tone is serious, factual, and structured. It is often used when dealing with highly technical or specialized topics. If your objective is to establish authority and credibility, this tone is the ideal.
It is often used in niches like finance, legal, or B2B (business addressing another business) communications.
Informal & conversational
This tone feels more relaxed and approachable, like conversing with a friend. It’s great for making complex ideas easier to understand and helps create a personal connection with readers.
This tone is ideal for Lifestyle blogs, how-to guides, and casual product reviews. It is also suitable for B2C (business addressing customers or consumers) audiences.
Inspiring & motivational
This writing tone is a good fit for a blog post if you want your reader to encourage, inspire, or motivate you.
This tone is mainly employed for self-improvement topics. It can also be used for Personal development blogs, fitness and wellness articles, and motivational content for B2C audiences.
Sarcastic & humorous
Use this tone If you want to add wit, sarcasm, and fun to your content. It’s less formal and often used to address topics playfully or critically without sounding too serious.
This is best for entertainment blogs, edgy brand marketing, or content that targets a younger audience (GenZ). It is suitable for B2C but rare for B2B unless the brand culture aligns.
IMPORTANT NOTE:

There is no one-size-fits-all tone for a specific industry. It always depends on the objective and the purpose of writing. Sometimes you need to mix two tones. For example, I often use a professionally engaging tone for B2B blogs. And sometimes, I use a formally conversational tone for B2C blogs.
Remember, just like readability, the writing tone depends on the audience you’re targeting.
But you MUST keep your writing tone consistent throughout the blog post.  If it's formal and professional at the start, the blog post must end in this same tone.
Also, keep your narrative tone consistent (First person as “I”, “me”, and second person as “you”, “your”).

6): Content Angle/Perspective
Here is how I put this;
There are hundreds of ways to discuss a certain topic, and a writer chooses the BEST way to present it.
So, The way you choose to present your message in a blog post is known as the content angle or perspective. This distinguishes a seasoned writer from a novice or non-writer.

You don’t just tell the reader something—you communicate it in the most compelling and impactful way possible. That’s the difference between writing something people read versus something people remember.
Although the concept is applicable even on a sentence level, let’s see some common content angles that we usually use in blog posts.
Common Content Angles in Blog Posts
There are several ways to frame your content, and the right angle depends on your audience and purpose.
Consider these angles when writing your next blog post;
Storytelling:

A narrative-driven approach that engages the reader emotionally. This angle is powerful for B2C content. I call it suitable for H2H (human-to-human) content.  It pulls readers in and makes the content relatable.
Fact/Stat Presenter:

A more objective, data-driven approach is ideal for (and normally used in) a B2B audience or when the writer needs to establish credibility. It appeals to logic and reason by presenting factual, straightforward information.
Opinionated:

Here, the writer takes a stance, sharing personal insights or bold opinions. This angle sparks conversations and debates. It's great for thought leadership pieces or niche topics where you want to stand out.
Problem-Solution:
Focused on identifying a problem and offering a solution. This works well for product reviews, how-to guides, and tutorials.

Again, remember that the content angle should always align with your objective and target audience. If your blog post is for normal human beings in daily life, use the storytelling angle. If you are writing for a business-minded audience, use the fact/stat presenter angle.
Maintain a Consistent Content Angle Throughout the Blog Post.

Once you choose a content angle, stick with it throughout the blog post. A common mistake I have seen is switching between angles, for instance, starting with a story and abruptly jumping into hard facts. It confuses readers and affects effectiveness.
The angle needs to be balanced and woven into every section, from the introduction to the conclusion.
7): Blog Post Formatting (for skimmers and scanner)
SEO content writing (blog posts and/or articles) is different from all other types and kinds of writing.
You write fiction books for book nerds.
You write creative stuff for writing lovers.
You write academic stuff for professors (& they don’t read:).
NONE of them requires you to format it properly. You can have long sentences, stretchy sentences, big walls of texts and no one will get bothered.
But SEO writing….that’s a totally different ball game.

You write blog posts to inform, educate, or promote something. And there you deal with skimmers and scanners. There you have to convey your message to those who are on the internet and they have 100s of other relatively better options than to read your blog post.
Their attention span is short. They are in a hurry.
And that’s where you need to format your post so that you can easily convey your message to skimmers and scanners.
Tell me, how will you write to someone you know is in a hurry, busy and short of time?
You will not write anything unnecessary → straight to the point.
You will highlight what is most important → emphasize main points.
You will write in clear & simple vocabulary → easy to read
You will try to be as concise as possible → no fluff.
This applies to the overall blog post.
Here is the universal structure of any blog post (or any writing in this case).
The introduction section…(first H2)
The most important part of your blog post is where you should spend 60% of your time (not a rule but my personal theory).
Why? The first 100-130 words are enough to make your reader realize whether the next 800-1000 words are going to be worth their 4-5 minutes or not.
Some SEO writers writes the introduction section when they are done with the rest of the blog post.
But I don’t do that. And I write the intro section in a way that it does not sound like an intro at all.
(Who needs the 100-130 words just to tell what is in the next 800 words?...NO ONE).
For short blog posts (600-1000 words)...get straight to the point and make your readers feel understood…talk about their pain points, problems. Take them to their ideal/desired situation.

Honestly, there is no set frameworks for writing a good introduction section of a blog post. You can use some copywriting frameworks like AIDA (Attention→Interest→Desire→Action), PAS (Problem→Agitate→Solution) ... etc.

But every blog post is different with a unique purpose, so you should not limit yourself to any formula. Just make sure your research is top notch, you know the best content angle and this first section is engaging and valuable enough.

Some writers (including me), often use a proper H2 just after the H1 (or SEO title) for the introduction section instead of writing a vague heading as “introduction” or having no heading at all (for instance, after the H1…write the introductory lines and then jump to the body of the blog post).
I use a proper subheading (as H2). For instance if I am writing a blog post on “How to Be More Productive”, I’d write “Productivity is Not an Accident”  as my H2 for the introduction section.
The Body (x main points)
This is where you have to deliver THE best…it’s the meat of your blog post.
One of the most important things to consider here is the heading hierarchy.

Remember, there is always ONLY one H1 in your blog post which we often use as the SEO title as well. Every major heading after that comes under H2. And any sub point in H2 comes under H3 and any sub point in H3 comes under H4….(but we rarely need to go beyond H3, unless the topic is 5k words how to guide).
Let say you’re writing a blog post in productivity niche on a topic ‘How To Be More Productive.’
Your H1 will be →  How To Be More Productive and Get your Work Done Faster
The first H2 (for intro section) will be → Productivity is not an Accident
Second H2 (for body section) will be → Top 8 Productivity Tips You Can Try Right Now
Now, each Tip will be a H3.
And if in any H3, we have an important subpoint we can use H4. But in our case, we are good with H3s.
This is normally what structuring a post means. But there is more to it.
Here are 4 other most important points you must consider.
In long listicles…you don’t need to explain each point in detail.
For instance you’re writing a how to guide and it includes 15 step….better to write each point within 100-150 words limit (or max 200 if a specific step really needs explanation).
It makes your writing concise, sharp and no-fluff.
There must be a balance of length (or word count in each section).
For instance, in our example of “How To Be More Productive and Get your Work Done Faster” the 8 tips’ section must have almost equal word count for each tip.
If your first tip is 150 words and the second is 250-300…it will sound awkward and disorganized.
But yes…10-20 word fluctuation is acceptable.
Always keep in mind this rule of thumb…
What does that mean? Your blog post should satisfy ONE specific purpose from start to end, addressing one group/sect/type of audience.
A good content is one which takes your reader from point A to point B…strategically, point by point, slowly, in a linear direction.
If I am writing a blog post on “How To Be More Productive and Get your Work Done Faster”, I will NOT discuss “what is productivity” or “why you need to be productive”, or "Benefits of productivity”.
My blog post from intro to the last heading will focus on ‘how to be productive’ with practical tips, personal experiences and SMEs quotes.

And my each tip will be the continuation of the previous one…a development. For instance, if my tip number 2 is about “Organize your day and create a to-do list”, the 3rd tip will be “Focus on the most important task first” and 4th will be “Don’t multitask”.

You see? There is an order. One can’t prioritize the most important task without having a to-do list and the focus on the most important task automatically helps eliminate all other distractions, hence no multitasking.
That’s what synchrony in content means.
That’s a must for the sake of skimmers and scanners.
Bold, All the important phrases and the sentences that are conveying the key message of your paragraph or a heading.
But I have seen writers underlining and bolding just keywords or one or two words.
The purpose of highlighting (by bolding, italicing, and underlining) is to make your most important sentence prominent. Don’t highlight the keywords or one or two word phrases.
The Conclusion Section
The word ‘conclusion’ here is misleading. It refers to “closing remarks,” “the ending,” or “summary.” But readers don’t want a conclusion for 800-1200 word blog posts.
When I started SEO blog writing, I made these mistakes;
- Name the last heading as ‘conclusion’
- Write some ‘closing remarks’ at the end.
- Or ‘wrap up’ my main arguments.
- Or ‘summarize’ everything.
Disclaimer: The intro, body, and conclusion sections vary from client to client, and there is no one-size-fits-all formula.

Then I realized (after research, experiments, and reading top blogs) that 1). It’s an ineffective & weak approach, 2). Digital readers are skimmers & scanners, 3). The conclusion isn’t applicable in the short-form blog post
And I changed my approach.
I started treating the last heading as a main heading.

8): The BLUF Approach for Writing Effectively

The BLUF (Bottom Line Upfront) approach, borrowed from military communication, is a straightforward and efficient method of conveying key information. It emphasizes placing the most critical message at the very start of your paragraph. The idea is to immediately give your readers the "bottom line" so they don’t have to dig through unnecessary details to understand the core point.
We can use this approach on individual sections/paragraphs and on overall blog posts.
Here is how;
How to Use the BLUF Approach in Paragraphs

To apply BLUF within a paragraph, start by distilling the most important idea and placing it at the beginning. Then, follow up with supporting information that expands on this core message. This keeps the writing sharp and to the point. It helps the readers The reader easily absorb the most relevant details.
For example:
BLUF Approach: "SEO content that focuses on user intent consistently ranks higher on Google."

That’s your bottom line. Everything that follows should support and elaborate on this main point. You could then explain how Google’s algorithms prioritize content that matches search queries and give examples of how user intent drives search behavior.
Contrast that with a more traditional approach, where you might build up to the main point gradually:
Traditional Approach:

"As Google’s algorithms have evolved over the years, they’ve begun to focus more on the intent behind search queries. In response, content strategies have shifted to better align with what users are looking for. SEO content needs to prioritize user intent to rank well on Google."
Notice how the key message is buried until the end.
In SEO writing, readers (and search engines) appreciate when you get straight to the point.

LSI (Latent Semantic Indexes) keywords: When you publish a blog…it has a specific topic in a specific category. It discusses a specific issue and provides a specific solution….
In simplest words, if your blog is about laptops…you will not discuss mobiles. If your blog is in the automotive niche, you will be focused on vehicles…and not touch health issues.

Ok, let’s put it in other words…Latent means ‘hidden’, non-obvious. Semantic is the meaning of a term (other related words/attributes/characteristics of a word). So, latent semantics are the hidden or non-obvious words or terms for a specific word. Indexing (in this context) is used for retrieving information (or gathering relevant information around a specific topic).

Latent semantic indexing (basically a term in NLP (natural language processing) is a method that classifies words based on their surroundings or context. As you know, one word has different meanings in different contexts.
Well…what’s the purpose of LSI in your blog?
When you publish your content online, the search engine (Google in our case) considers related terms to understand your content…and match the overall text with ‘search intent’.
It helps search engines understand the ‘relevancy’ of content.
In other words…LSI creates an overall ‘environment’ that helps search engines deeply understand specific content.
Note: LSI and synonyms are not the same thing. Synonyms are part of LSI terms…but not necessarily the synonym of a keyword.

For instance…the synonyms for laptop are palmtop, minicomputer, or microcomputer. But the LSI terms (that goes along with laptop) are storage, performance, RAM/ROM, gaming, editing…or some parts of a laptop like display, keyboard, touchpad, etc.
Another silly & non-related example (which our linguistic professor used to give us) is
Needle…needle is semantically related to pain, threading, sewing, etc.

Having a list of related terms helps you cover your blog better and helps Google understand your content more deeply.

What is logical flow and how to do it? I’ll tell you exactly but first let’s understand what is disruptive flow and why it’s a bad thing.

<H2> Sleep More

This logical flow is also called “Content Coherance”.
When from start (intro section) to end (conclusion section) your piece is well “knitted: and has a logical flow, it’s a coherent content.
There are two levels of coherence;
It’s a connection between words and sentences at a textual level. In other words, the meaning of each sentence should flow naturally into the next.
For example, if you're discussing "tuning out distractions," the following sentence should expand on that idea, like "start by silencing notifications."

Remove all distractions from your workspace. Begin by silencing notifications on your phone, then lock it away in a drawer. Clear your desk of any unnecessary items and leave only the essentials needed for your work. This will help you maintain focus and productivity.

Which version made more sense?
The first one. Why? Because all three out of four sentences were “semantically” connected with the idea of “remove all distractions”...the first sentence.

It refers to how well one concept leads into the next. And when you complete a “section”, all the ideas discussed in it makes an overall logical sense.
