And you can NEVER achieve this if you don’t know the “craft”.

I present an analogy here; you can have all the equipments a carpenter use, but will not be able to build a building until you know how to use those equipments and unless you have had spent time “learning” how to build buildings.
ChatGPT or any AI tool is just that equipment.

I can go on and on but what I really want to say is that, declare ChatGPT as your RED ZONE.  And Never enter into it. Never open it until you know…. your skill has been matured enough that no AI can impact it.
The other major drawback is that ChatGPT’s content is generic and repetitive which fail to make any real difference. This repetition occurs on so many levels. Let’s understand this;

You want to write a blog post and don’t know about the topic, you have no prior research and does not know the search intent of the searcher. In this sense, you will write a generic prompt without any specific details. ChatGPT will come up with generic outlines and those generic outlines will lead to generic outlines and repetitive information.

Let’s say you a lifestyle blog writer, and often write for clothing brands. And you are working for two different clients, but rely on ChatGPT to write your content. You will never be able to differentiate the tone and style between the two. Content will sounds like a duplicate of each other.

Let's say, you and another writer are writing on a same topic….and you’ve both given ChatGPT a general prompt to write the outlines. It will 90% write the same outlines and after that you will get 90% the same content.

Think it in a bigger picture. If this is what every other blog writer is doing, the time is not that far when all we have on Google will be AI cluttered content. We are already going through content shock. Please don’t make people hate blogs:).
So, when is the best time to use or get help from ChatGPT?

When your writing tone and research skills are matured enough that AI can’t effect it and you have been working hard on the the craft to polish your tone and style, then you can freely use AI. It may take 6 months or 6 years, but stick to it.
Because at that time you will exactly know the difference  between good and bad writing.

You will be able to edit/tweak/modify AI writing as per your tone and style. You will know what words are not the best choice and what to choose instead. And at that time you will also be able to write “custom” prompts and you will exactly know how to edit and refine AI content to infuse a life in your words.
Ranking Blog Audits
Instead of me writing a whole new blog post, I decided to audit already ranking blog posts for our selected topic ‘How to be more productive’.
Because this way I can better tell you what’s possibly working, as the blog posts are already ranking.
Let’s audit the ranking blog posts for our selected topic.
Blog Post 1: 18 Habits of Highly Productive People: What Efficient People Have in Common
Title
“18 Habits of Highly Productive People: What Efficient People Have in Common”
Although the title exceeds the visible character count limit (which is 55-65 characters), it’s clear and catchy.
Clear as the readers know exactly what they will get: a list of habits that productive people share.

It's catchy (to me) because of phrases like ‘highly productive people’ and ‘efficient people have in common.’ These two phrases hit my desire to be highly productive and efficient. Also, after reading these phrases, I subconsciously thought about highly successful (financially) people like Elon Musk and Gates.
The phrase ‘have in common’ is triggering my curiosity. I want to know the common behaviors or traits that those efficient people have.
The title also provides me with social proof. It suggests that successful and efficient people use these habits, and I can follow them to achieve the same level of productivity.
The number ‘18’ adds specificity. It tells me how lengthy the list is and what to expect.
An effective title can be templated into [What] +  [why/how/for whom it matters]. In other words, a good title is the combination of the two elements: What + why/how/whom.
And the title under discussion is a good example of this framework.
What = 18 productivity habits of highly productive people
Why (it matters) = because efficient people have them all (in common).
Intro Section
The whole introduction is relatable. Although it does not present anything new, it validates what we usually feel/think when thinking about productivity.

That one picture-perfect person (even if we don’t have one in our circle) comes to mind. And we nod along. We all have a desire to be just like that one super-productive, robotic, and machine-like person arises.
We all want to finish our hour-long work in 20 minutes and get things done early.
It’s a shared experience, and we get curious and excited to learn the secret. We get a green light that, yes, this is the blog post that will make me productive like that one ideal person.
How can you apply this to ANY blog’s intro section?
The introduction is a fine mixture of clarity and creativity.
It fulfills the (twofold) purpose;
Unlike other intros, it does not directly mention what we are going to read in the blog post. Instead, it indirectly addresses this by asking two questions.
Subheadings and Overall Content Audit

This blog is lengthy (6K+ words) with 20 subheadings (18 for tips). It’s a listicle, and the key content is the 18 tips. I will not audit each subheading, but let’s discuss the first subheading, ' Focus on the most important tasks (MITs) first.’
Although the idea is generic and sounds obvious. But the angle they used to present it is unique, especially the acronym MITs.

The first sentence is the play on words. Massachusetts Institute of Technology is a well-known scientific and technological training and research institution. Many of the readers of this blog post would never have been to MIT, but alluding to the institution and then claiming that an MIT (most important task) can help you be more productive is where you feel compelled to read the rest of the content of this heading.
The second paragraph expands the idea further, explaining the theory behind MIT. Reading this, you can easily differentiate an inefficient, less important, and most important task.
The third paragraph makes the overall heading more effective and tells the reader how ignoring MIT can lead to procrastination. It tells the consequences of not having an MIT list.
The fourth paragraph is an ‘actionable’ tip to implement the MITs technique.
The fifth paragraph is about the aftereffects of implementing that technique.
But the writer knows the reader still needs confirmation, so they brought productivity coach and expert ‘Laura Earnest’ to share her thoughts on prioritizing MIT.
So here is the framework that the writer used in this heading (that you can use to write a similar subheading for any given topic) ;

[An attention-grabbing first sentence–done by alluding to something famous] + [Explanation of the idea given in the heading] + [Consequences of ignoring the idea (i.e not creating MIT list)] + [Actionable tip] + [Aftereffects of implementing the technique] +  [credible source (expert quote here, but you can use stats, research report or any relevant proven data)].

Most importantly, the content of this subheading is logical and conceptually coherent. The writer grabbed your attention, explained the idea, described the benefit, presented an actionable tip, mentioned the aftereffects, and then backed it up with an expert quote.
This is what I call the “internal coherence’ of the content.
There is another element in the content of a highly effective blog post, and I call it  ‘overall coherence’. I’ll tell you exactly how the writer implemented it in this blog post.
As the 18 subheadings are the key content of this blog post…why did the writer decide to make this subheading the very first one?
Because before anything else, you need to determine where you need to be productive…
It’s more than just making a to-do list. It is about pruning it and knowing what tasks need your attention first.

In this sense, the remaining 17 tips are built on that one. For instance, the second subheading is ‘cultivate deep work’, which is only possible when you know your most important task. The third subheading is ‘keep a distraction list to stay focused’. Working deeply is only possible when you are conscious of distractions. I can go on and on, but you get the idea.

Now imagine randomly writing the 18 tips. Place the third one in first place and the fourth one in second place…and you will notice that eventually, even though the content is the same, it’s not effective. It will feel disjointed.
So, your responsibility as a writer is to help your reader move from point A to point B and then to point C. This applies to non-listicles as well.
Next time you write a listicle, never write it randomly. Make sure each point/subheading correlates with its predecessor and successor.
You will notice similar patterns in all 18 tips. Each subheading offers unique insights, novel perspectives, expert quotes, and effective arguments.
Remember, whenever you’re writing a blog post in a non-technical niche or in a niche with a general audience or topics relevant to any human being, there will already be loads of content published.

Almost all of the information would already be covered. So, you need to bring novelty or present the same idea with a different twist. Just like this blog post under discussion — we already have so much content on the topic, but when you read this blog post, you will notice that 80-85% of the content is “something new” to you.
Your responsibility as a writer is to do better than what’s already out there. That’s where your research skills come into play. That's when you need to lean on your creative instincts.
Conclusion section
As the blog post is 6000+ words…the writer needed to recap the whole thing.
But just before the recap, the writer used two pointers to make this conclusion section effective.
In other words, the first paragraph/section synthesizes the whole blog post by classifying the 18 tips into 4 categories.

The second section/paragraph offers something ‘extra,’ like a further expansion of the blog post. It can stand alone as a separate tip…but writing it in the conclusion section makes it more effective and connects all 18 tips—like when nothing from those 18 tips is working, one should ask for help.
Blog Post 3: 10 ways to boost your productivity at work
Title
Let’s break down the title.
‘10 ways’

Numbers in a blog post title usually refer to a listicle format. The common perception is that readers are naturally attracted to listicles because they know exactly what they’re getting—clear, digestible, and actionable information. This is a classic approach that works well for drawing clicks, especially in blog articles.
‘boost your productivity’

This phrase offers a direct benefit and taps into a problem-solution framework. It suggests readers may not be performing optimally at work and offers solutions for improvement. It uses implied WIIFM (What's In It For Me?), a basic copywriting principle where the benefit is clear to the reader.
‘at work’

The phrase "at work" makes the title audience-specific. The readers could be professionals or employees looking to improve their work habits. It appeals directly to a broad but relevant group of readers.
But this title is mediocre.
It’s not bad, but it lacks the punch that would make it exceptionally compelling or click-worthy. Let's dissect why:

It’s overused and generic:The combination of "ways to boost productivity" is ubiquitous. It’s a generic phrase that gets diluted in a sea of similar titles across the internet. People have likely seen "boost productivity" countless times, which can reduce its click appeal. You need something fresh or unique in competitive niches like self-improvement or productivity.

It misses emotional appeal:The title lacks emotional engagement. Effective titles often trigger emotions—whether excitement, urgency, or curiosity. The title doesn't spark curiosity or a desire for immediate action. It doesn’t feel urgent or compelling enough for the reader to think, “I need to read this now.”

It has no unique value proposition (UVP):There’s nothing that differentiates this article from others on productivity. What makes these "10 ways" special or different from any other blog on the same topic? Highlighting an unusual method, secret hack, or expert-backed advice could give it an edge.
Here’s how I’d have written this title;
Introduction Section
Let’s dissect the whole introduction section.
1. Opening Line:
“Use these powerful strategies to get more done (while stressing less).”
This is a headline-like teaser that introduces the entire listicle and creates intrigue.
The opening sentence (which we called a ‘strong opener’ in the previous intro section analysis) is the MOST important first sentence.
The opening sentence of this intro section promises a clear benefit—getting more done while stressing less—which is an appealing hook for the target audience.
Workplaces are usually stressful places. So, the phrase “stressing less” evokes a sense of control and ease and directly triggers the readers' dealing with workplace stress.
The opening is concise and straight, giving readers an immediate reason to continue.
But it has a weakness. It sounds more like a subheading than part of a cohesive narrative. It is somewhat disconnected from the next paragraph and lacks a smooth transition.
2. First Paragraph:
“You reach the end of your workday and glance down at your (now coffee-stained) to-do list. You’re immediately overcome with frustration as you realize that barely half the tasks are checked off.”
This paragraph uses the "relatable story" approach. It creates a scene in which the reader is directly involved through a second-person narrative ("you").

The frustration of not checking off tasks on a to-do list is highly relatable. It taps into a common problem experienced by workers everywhere, and the casual mention of the “coffee-stained” to-do list adds an extra layer of realism and daily-life imagery.
This technique builds empathy with the reader by reflecting on a common pain point.
The sensory detail (“coffee-stained”) makes the experience more tangible and relatable.
The only shortcoming I can think of in this paragraph is that sentence structure is slightly long-winded. Breaking it into two shorter sentences would make it snappier.
3. Second Paragraph:
“Seriously, what happened? You’ve been at your desk for the better part of eight hours. Why didn’t you get more accomplished?”
This paragraph uses a casual, almost colloquial tone, which improves the narrative's relatability. The rhetorical questions invite readers to reflect on their productivity struggles.
Asking questions actively engages the reader and makes them think about their situation and why it may have gone wrong.
It further engages the reader by directly addressing their internal dialogue (“Why didn’t I get more done?”).
The informal tone makes the piece conversational and approachable — which connects readers.
I loved this paragraph. So no apparent weakness here.
4. Third Paragraph:
“Maintaining a high level of productivity is not intuitive or easy – but you don’t have to resign yourself to feeling discouraged and depleted at the end of every workday.”

This paragraph shifts from the emotional frustration of being unproductive to a more rational and solution-oriented perspective. It reassures the reader that although productivity is tough, change is possible.

The writer is using a classic copywriting technique here called         “problem-acknowledgement.” Acknowledging that productivity is “not intuitive or easy” builds trust. Readers feel understood when their struggles are validated.

The writer then used the “positive-reframe” technique, where you give your reader a green light after acknowledging the problem. The phrase “you don’t have to resign yourself” offers hope, subtly implying that the following content will provide solutions.
Notice how smoothly the paragraph transitioned from problem identification (frustration) to hope (solutions exist).
The tone is very suitable here. It is encouraging and makes readers feel empowered.
5. Fourth Paragraph (CTA):
“We rounded up ten top-notch, rock-solid tips you can put into play to channel your focus and defeat your to-do list – plus a quiz to help get you started.”
This sentence signals that actionable solutions are about to be delivered. It is the call to read the whole blog post.
But the CTA includes an additional offer: a quiz. This provides added value.
The only thing I did not like that much was the use of buzzwords like “top-notch” and “rock-solid.” It feels overhyped to me.
Now the most important part of this breakdown; how can you use this intro section format/framework to write any blog post’s introduction?
Let me template this for you.
[Attention-Grabbing Teaser] + [Relatable Pain Point] + [Rhetorical Reflection] + [Problem Acknowledgment] + [CTA for the Main Content].
Start with a brief sentence or headline-like teaser that hints at the solution or benefit (e.g., “Use these [adjective] strategies to [solve a problem or achieve benefit].”).
Relatable Pain Point (First paragraph):
Open with a scene or a specific situation that readers can easily identify with. Use sensory details and second-person narrative to make it personal.
Rhetorical Reflection (Second paragraph):
Ask rhetorical questions to make the reader pause and reflect on their experiences. Keep the tone conversational.
Problem Acknowledgment (Third paragraph):
Acknowledge the problem's difficulty while offering a subtle hint that solutions are coming.
CTA to read the blog post (Fourth paragraph):
Briefly introduce the upcoming tips or advice, and give your readers a reason to read the whole blog post.
Overall Key Content Audit (and what you can learn and use for any blog post)
We analyzed how to write effective headings in the previous blog post audit. In this audit, let’s discuss the overall blog post.

First of all, note that the blog post is published by ATLASSIAN. It is a team management software, so it’s basically in the SaaS niche. The target audience is project managers, IT and Operation teams, Marketing teams, small and large enterprises, etc.
The good stuff;
The post is filled with highly actionable and practical advice.

Each point provides readers with clear, simple steps they can take to improve their productivity. For example, "Manage your energy, not just your time" advises keeping a journal to find your productivity peaks. Journaling is a habit of many successful professionals in the SaaS field. So, by reading this, the reader knows exactly how to manage their time best. And it is easy to implement and a tangible solution.
Each of the 10 points are well-organized.

The subheadings are descriptive and clear. For instance, “Build a better to-do list”; just by reading it, you’ll know what’s coming. Such subheadings make it easier to skim and immediately understand what each section covers, which is especially effective for professionals with limited reading time.
The blog effectively incorporates expert insights.

The post includes quotes from experts like Dr. Melissa Gratias (workplace productivity coach), which add credibility and authority. Professionals believe in credible sources. You can’t just give your opinion out of thin air. So, whenever writing a blog post for such an audience, always back up your claims with some source of expert quotes, stats, or facts.
The tone is conversational yet professional (what I call professionally engaging).

It strikes a balance that engages SaaS users like project managers and teams. The blog speaks directly to the reader’s pain points in a relatable way (“You’re human—you won’t operate at peak efficiency all day, every day”), which keeps the audience invested.
The post

Bullet points within headings make the content digestible and more accessible. This is particularly useful for skimmers and scanners who are in a hurry and may want to quickly find the sections most relevant to them.
The blog has a data-driven approach.

Points like "You use different parts of your brain for different tasks" and "Research shows that the human brain is actually incapable of multitasking" add scientific backing, appealing to the logical, detail-oriented mindset of project managers and IT professionals.
The post has a variety of productivity methods.

The post caters to a diverse audience by offering different approaches, such as task batching, time blocking, and the Pomodoro technique. Everyone can find a method that resonates with their work style — an intelligent tactic for broadening the appeal.
Somehow baddie stuff;
There are some complex ideas that need to be simplified.

The first point introduces "ultradian rhythms" and biological cycles, which might be too technical for some readers in this field. While it adds credibility, the explanation could be simplified. Instead of mentioning complex terms, the writer could focus on how energy fluctuates naturally during the day and how readers can use that to their advantage.
The lesson for you?
Avoid jargon or medical terms unless absolutely necessary, and explain things in plain, relatable (to your TA) language.
There is a bit of repetition in concepts.

Some of the tips feel repetitive. For example, the advice on "task switching" in Point 4 and "batching tasks" in Point 5 is quite similar. Both stress focusing on one thing at a time but in slightly different ways. A more concise and focused explanation of these overlapping concepts would help keep the post tighter and avoid redundancy.
Lesson?
Never repeat a concept twice in a blog post.
There is a bit of inconsistency in the depth of some points.

Some points, like "Refine your workspace" and "Change your scenery," lack depth. These tips are somewhat generic, especially when compared to more nuanced points like "Let go of perfectionism." The readers are now expecting the same in-depth exploration of how workspace setups specifically impact productivity in SaaS environments.
Lesson?
There must be a consistency of research depth throughout the blog post. Keep
Conclusion Section
The heading is non-generic and action-oriented.

“Take control of your productivity at work" avoids the typical generic conclusion labels like "Conclusion" or "Final Thoughts.” This approach engages the reader rather than signaling the end of the conversation. The content feels open-ended and action-oriented.
First Paragraph

The first paragraph acknowledges a relatable problem: “Most of us have a lot to do... it’s hard to muster the motivation and make the most of your time at work.” This is effective as it reintroduces the challenge the reader is likely facing. The writer has maintained an emotional connection through this para and also reinforced the relevance of the article's content.
Second Paragraph

The second paragraph broadens the topic by reminding readers that productivity isn’t constant: “The truth is that you’re human – you won’t operate at peak efficiency all day, every day.” This sentiment makes the conclusion more realistic and empathetic rather than placing unrealistic expectations on the reader.

The follow-up with “plenty of things you can try to boost your productivity” gives a gentle call to action, highlighting that while perfection isn't expected, improvement is possible. This keeps the reader thinking about the content and encourages them to act without feeling pressured.

The tone in the conclusion is consistent with the rest of the post—professionally engaging yet relatable. The flow is smooth, transitioning from problem acknowledgment to action and motivation without abruptly summarizing the post. This helps readers reflect on the content without losing momentum.
This is a well-executed approach to closing the post without being too final, leaving the reader to consider the next steps.
How NOT to Write a Blog Post
Blog Post Example: How to be more productive: 10 productivity tips

This blog post is ranking at the first position (at the time I am doing all of this) and is even beating ActiveCampaign and Atlassian, but this is an instance of how I would never write a blog post. And I’ll tell you exactly why in the following pointers.
The introduction section is weak and not compelling.

It lacks a strong hook and doesn’t clearly outline the value the reader will gain. It begins with a general and obvious question: “Struggling to feel productive?”  It’s not a strong opening, as obviously the reader wants to be more productive and they are struggling with it, that’s the only reason they on this blog post.
If you call it the “identification of a problem,” I’d say it's really weak and bland.

The third sentence is again a question, just like the first sentence. It sounds repetitive. And never ask more than one question (even if it’s a rhetorical) in your introduction section...otherwise you will lose the effectiveness of your narrative. Never ask a direct question because teh answer in that case will be subjective. And you don’t know the exact answer. The psychology behind asking a rhetorical question is that your entire blog post is then the answer to that rhetorical question.
There are unnecessary subheadings that clearly deviate from search intent.
The blog post includes several subheadings that deviate from the primary focus of teaching readers how to be more productive.
For example:

"What is productivity?" shifts from practical productivity tips to defining a term that most readers already understand. People who search for “how to be more productive” are usually looking for actionable steps, not theoretical explanations. So this heading is disrupting the flow of the blog post and doesn’t align with the search intent.

"What is toxic productivity?" also pulls the reader in a different direction. While this is an interesting topic, it doesn’t serve the reader's goal of learning about productivity techniques. It is not the “key content” as the readers are not concerned about the ‘types of productivity’. This section could be better suited to an entirely different post that focuses on avoiding burnout or toxic productivity, instead of one that promises tips to enhance productivity.

"How to be more productive at work" adds little value since the entire blog post is supposed to be about improving productivity in the first place. It's a redundant subheading that doesn’t contribute to the overall flow and can be omitted. Simply diving into the productivity tips would maintain focus and keep readers engaged.
So the rule of thumb here is that just after the introduction section, directly jump to the key content.
The blog post has generic/Vague subheadings.
Some of the subheadings in the post are too brief or vague, which detracts from their impact and leaves the reader unsure of what value the tips will provide. For example:

"Set small goals" doesn’t fully capture the importance of breaking down large tasks. It would be more effective to phrase the heading in a way that highlights the benefit, such as “Break Down Large Tasks for Steady Progress.” So that the reader can get a clear idea of what to expect and why the tip matters.

"Take a break" is similarly too generic. This could be improved to something like “Take Strategic Breaks to Increase your Focus.” The idea here is to explain why the advice is useful in the subheading itself.

"Delegate" is another common term that needs more depth. A more descriptive subheading could be something like “Increase Efficiency by Delegating the Right Tasks.” This adds value to the reader by clarifying the benefit and aligning the heading with actionable advice.
That’s why I always say sub/heading should always be descriptive, clear and meaningful.
The conclusion is typical and generic.

The post wraps up with the subheading "Final thoughts," which isn’t particularly engaging or memorable. This kind of conclusion feels more like a summary, which can leave the reader feeling unsatisfied. Instead, the conclusion should synthesize the key points or encourage the reader to take action based on what they’ve learned. Something like “Productivity is Never an Accident” would be more impactful because it encourages the reader to ‘grind’ and make ‘being productive’ a habit while implementing all the tips discussed.

sections.content: Your Most pressing questions are answered here
How to Write a “good” blog post?
My junior writers (in my team) often ask me this question.
“Saiq, can you tell me the exact formula for writing a ‘good’ blog post?”
My answers vary every single time.
TBH, there is no pet and exact formula to write a good blog post.
Good is subjective. And good is not measurable (formulas are used for something measurable).
For Google, the ‘good’ blog post signal is EEAT.
Google considers;
For how long has a reader stayed on the page?
How many social media shares did the blog earn?
How many other websites referred to the blog post?
A blog ticking at least these three (yes, there are many) is ‘Good’ for Google.
If we talk about humans…and what they consider as ‘good’, then I can think of things like;
Now, every topic is contextual. By context, I mean the nature of the topic and the target audience. Every blog post has a different and ‘unique’ purpose and serves a unique set of audiences.
I have tried many copywriting formulas on blog posts…some of them are;

Now, this is my observation and categorization of applying different formulas on different levels (or what we call the ‘journey of a reader). Of course you can apply PAS to Bofu or AIDA to pass. And as I said…it’s always contextual.
Here are some more formulas I try often;
Your blog should be clear, concise, compelling, and credible.
(Yes, it’s a formula, too)

The goal is to write a meaningful, quality blog that is EEAT-aligned and satisfies search intent. The methodology and writing approach may vary with each blog post, but the end goal is the same, as I mentioned.
How much should I charge for a blog post of 1000-1200 words?
Money = value
Your clients pay you because you are adding some kind of value to their life.Here are some reasons someone hired you to write a blog post;
As an SEO writer, you can 100% tick the first two; the latter two depend on many factors…and are not in your full control, but they are possible if you do good work.
Your client doesn’t hire you just to type some words and fulfill the formality of publishing blog posts.
So, first of all, evaluate what you can do for your client. How much value can you provide? The more value you provide, the more you deserve to get paid.
But…that’s not the answer to your question.

If you just started and have never written for a client, I’d highly suggest that you WORK FOR FREE, especially for an inexperienced (individual) SEO writer. Reach out to them and offer your help. Tell them that you will write for free, but you will need their detailed feedback on your write-up. This is the best way to learn and upskill instead of charging pennies and getting rejected every time. I do that for my junior writers…it’s been a year now, and I have 1 such student at a time. I ‘graduated’ three till now.
When I started SEO blog writing after working as an academic writer for over a year, I charged based on my time and effort.

My first-ever client paid me $25 for a 2000-word blog (and she was from the US). I spent 7-8 hours researching and writing. It was about October-December in 2021, and the dollar was under 200 PKR(170-175). So, I got paid 4,250 PKR for 2000 words, or 2.1 PKR per word, and that too from an international client.
Then, with time, when my writing skills improved a bit….my clients used to pay me $30-35  for a blog (no matter the word count) from early 2023 to around August 2023.

During that period (Jan 2023-Aug 2023), I focused on upskilling and learning on-page SEO and other necessary stuff to polish my SEO blogs. In the last quarter of 2023 (Aug - Dec), I was in a position where I could negotiate the prices…I’d close a deal between 35-50 bucks for an 800-1200 word blog post. Now (June 2024), I charge way more than 50 bucks per post.
You get the idea of what I’m talking about, right?
So now let’s talk about you.
Look at yourself. Where do you stand?

If you are totally new…with little to ZERO experience working with a client. But if you know the basics of on-page SEO and how to research and write content that actually makes sense and is helpful for the readers then you are FREE to charge whatever you want to charge.
Again let me REPEAT…
Only if you know how to RESEARCH and write content that actually MAKES SENSE and is HELPFUL for the readers.
Let’s talk about some numbers (and this my own evaluation, you’re free to agree or disagree).

If you are a newbie (you’ve written less than 10 blogs for clients), a justified rate would be 15-20 bucks (or 3k-5k PKR) for an 800-1000-word blog post…and $25-30 for a 1500-2000-word blog post. If you have done your practice and know the research process, you will need 6-7 hours of focused work for a 1000-1200-word write-up.
If you are a mid-level blog writer (you’ve written more than 50 blog posts for clients), and you have some testimonials and a track record, then you are in a position to negotiate the prices a bit.

That’s a phase where the ‘show, don’t tell’ formula applies. Ask about your client’s budget. Tell them how much you charged for something similar to your previous client. You can close the deal between 30-50 (6k-8k PKR) bucks for a 1000-1500 word blog post.
Now….here are some other important factors you should keep in mind…
Working with local or international clients?
Or shall I rephrase this into “working with developing countries or developed countries clients”?

Developing countries’ clients usually have low budgets. They need more work done in the least possible budget. But again, remember that’s not the case with every client. So, before making any judgments, evaluate the position of your client. You will literally be able to guess it in the first 10-15 messages (or in the first 1-3 minutes of e-meeting them).

I never worked with any local (Pakistani) client. But my fellow writers often tell me that you learn and practice more when working with local clients. I think this is because you don’t have a communication gap with them; they tell you clearly what they want, and you convey exactly what you think and can do.
Local clients pay in local currencies…so always quote them in local currency.
Once, I was looking for a writer and reached out to one…and the girl quoted me in dollars (that too, what she used to quote to her UK/US clients).
Never forget the context in which you are dealing.
Working directly or any job platform?

How do I know my writing is good?
I’ll give you some practical advice in a while, but first, let me clarify something.

There is no benchmark of ‘good’ writing. This means you can’t decide whether your writing is good or bad. There are no ‘objectively’ good writers and good work. You can’t measure how good a piece of writing is. Good is subjective. Sometimes, what seems good to me looks terrible to others, and vice versa.
Generally, a good write-up is flowy, clear, meaningful, authentic, and original.

Flowy = There is a coherence in ideas from start to end. Each paragraph continues the bigger idea while simultaneously ‘revealing’ new information. Each heading/subheading is the continuation of the bigger idea while at the same time fulfilling its certain purpose. Your blog post has a proper structure and a formating framework from the start to end.

Clear = The content clearly conveys what you want to say to your ideal reader. No unnecessary phrases. No difficult vocabulary (words that your reader doesn’t have to look up in a dictionary for meanings). No passive voice (until it’s unavoidable). Less to no use of filler words (basically, actually, just, you know, etc.)

Meaningful = When someone grabs a pen and paper and starts jotting gibberish…it would be meaningless. If someone takes the time to understand the ‘what’, ‘why’, and ‘ to whom’ before writing anything…it would be meaningful writing. Meaningful writing is a ‘response’. It’s effective. It has a certain purpose. As a writer, you choose the most suitable word within a specific content and write each sentence carefully. You infuse life into your words.

Authentic = Your writing is believable in the real-world setting and backed up with credible sources and citations. No exaggeration. No false claims. Practical and delivering on the promise you made in your headline or intro.

Original = If you copy-pasted others’ opinions, formats, structures, and information, you are not writing something original….you’re simply plagiarizing. Original writing contains something new…something of your own. It might be your opinion, observation, analysis, prediction, or derived idea.
All good.
